comment.author: 63413954@N00
comment._content: Umbrella reads "Parade starts at Wash. Sq. 5pm"

comment.author: 23176588@N02
comment._content: This is pretty amazing - a photo of women preparing to demonstrate in a parade, petitioning for the right to vote.  Almost 100 years later we now have a woman running for the office of President.

comment.author: 94604596@N00
comment._content: The leading suffregette in NYC at this period was Fannie Garrison Villard who I suspect this is in the photo.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Frank G1: Thanks for your information. As you said, the woman second from the right could possibly be Frances Garrison Villard (1844-1928). I found one picture of her in 1887 here: www.rochester.lib.ny.us:2080/cgi-bin/cw_cgi?fullRecord+64... Do you have any images of her closer to the date of the Bain image for comparison?

comment.author: 17643926@N00
comment._content: These women and girls were possibly on their way to march in a parade that took place on Saturday, May 4, 1912 and started from Washington Square in New York City, according to the NY Times article, "Sufferage Army Out On Parade." According to the paper, "Promptly, at five o'clock . . . the order to start the parade came." Over a thousand men marched in the parade alongside the women.
